node.title: This pioneering Australian woman was sawn in half 11,800 times
node.alt: A black and white portrait of Esme Levante
node.description: The world of stage magic in Australia was a male affair, until Esme Levante, Myrtle Roberts and Moi-Yo Miller came along.
node.content:
["The large wooden trunk on stage is clearly empty.", "Esme Levante, dressed in a glamorous evening gown and fine jewelry, inspects it and bangs on the base \u2014 there's nothing inside.", "Ms Levante proceeds to pack several delicate furs\u00a0into the trunk. Then, as the band reaches a crescendo, she quickly closes and reopens it.", "The furs\u00a0are nowhere to be seen. In their place, a dazed wallaby emerges.", "Cue the gasps, followed by riotous applause.", "The year was 1960 and Australian magician Ms Levante was performing one of her signature tricks on French television.", "The grainy black and white footage is part of\u00a0a new digital exhibition on pioneering Australian women in magic at the Arts Centre Melbourne.", "", "
During her career, Esme performed magic for British and European royalty.\u00a0(Supplied:\u00a0Will Alma Collection, State Library of Victoria)
", "In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, stage magic started to boom around Europe and the US, with Australia following suit.", "\"When we think about [the development of modern stage magic], we may think of women as 'just assistants' \u2026 But there were women who were performers and magicians in their own right,\" the exhibition's curator Cathy Pryor says.", "Three Australian women \u2014 Esme Levante, Myrtle Roberts and Moi-Yo Miller \u2014 began their careers in the 1920s and 1930s, and went on to perform for decades.", "\"Stage magic was very much a male-dominated scene. It would have been very tough for them to make a name for themselves,\" Ms Pryor says.", "And in a profession which still experiences a gender divide in Australia, the legacies of these three women are as important as ever.", "
From the Himalayas to the Riviera\u00a0
", "Born in 1921, Esme Cole was the daughter of one of Australia's most accomplished magicians, Les Cole, and his performer wife, Gladys Cole.", "", "
Esme was the daughter of one of Australia's foremost magicians, the Great Levante.(Supplied: Australian Performing Arts Collection)
", "Les, who went by the stage name the Great Levante, decided Esme would join in with the family's travelling magic shows from a very young age.", "\"She first appeared on stage when she was five years old \u2026 She did a marionette act, with little puppets which she manipulated to do a dance\u00a0and sing,\" Esme's son Maxwell Hunt says.", "Esme soon became an accomplished magician and escapologist, playing a bigger role in her father's shows, which toured Australia before heading overseas to Asia and Europe.", "\"One tour lasted something like 12 or 13 years \u2026 They went from a hill station in the Himalayas to a town on the northwest frontier of Pakistan, near the Afghan border, and sometimes barely escaped with their lives,\" says author John Zubrzycki, who is researching Australian popular culture in Asia in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.", "In one of her most famous tricks, Ms Levante was tied up in chains and leg irons, then jumped from a diving board into a pool. She managed to free herself and triumphantly emerge from the water.", "The years and the performances went by. In 1956,\u00a0Ms Levante decided to develop a solo cabaret show, which Ms Pryor says was \"quite a classy one-woman act.\"", "She toured all over Europe (including the French television appearance), with her second husband George Hunt serving as the magician's assistant.", "An Australian Variety News article from 1968, which appears in the exhibition, said, \"Esme\u00a0has presented her act many times before members of the British Royal Family as well as crowned heads of Europe.\"", "\"One of Esme's many successful showplaces has been the French Riviera, where the sophistication of the jet set in the gay casinos provided an ideal background for an act such as Esme Levante.\"", "But Claudia Funder, a research coordinator at the Australian Performing Arts Collection at the Arts Centre Melbourne, says unfortunately, \"there's not a lot of documentary evidence in her personal archive about her grand career.\"", "\"These women seem to be second fiddle to the main male magician acts [from last century].\"", "
The 'Electric Spark'
", "Myrtle Roberts' business card said it all: \"Myrtle Roberts: Australia's Foremost Lady of Magic.\"", "Born in 1908, Ms Roberts started her stage career in the suburban vaudeville halls around Melbourne, before being hired as a showgirl at the Tivoli Theatre.", "", "
Myrtle Roberts essentially taught herself how to be a magician.\u00a0(Supplied: Pete Smith)
", "\"Her way of moving out of [the showgirl] world was to create her own variety act. And part of that was performing magic. So she basically taught herself how to be a magician,\" Ms Pryor says.", "She perfected a number of \"small magic\" illusions including rope and cylinder tricks and releasing birds from a dish of fire.", "One of Ms Roberts' acts was the \"Electric Spark,\" where\u00a0she tap-danced on a table with a low electrical current running through it, sending sparks flying from her tap shoes.", "In another act, performed at Luna Park, she was sealed inside a giant block of ice before emerging in a swimming costume.", "But Ms Roberts had many talents \u2014 with a 1946 review featured in the exhibition calling her \"the most versatile artist on the Australian stage.\"", "\"Who else can equal this array of ability \u2014 soubrette, comedienne, radio artist, principal boy, pantomime, magician and crack rifle shot,\" it read.", "In an interview uncovered for the exhibition, Ms Roberts said she was a perfectionist.", "\"If I bought a pair of pigeons, they were the best. If I bought a bunny rabbit, he was an Angora rabbit. If I had anything made, it was always the best,\" she told the ABC in 1979.", "", "
Myrtle Roberts (left)\u00a0with Vic Gordon, Gwendow Paul, John Newman and Tikki Taylor at Tikki and John's Theatre Restaurant\u00a0in 1967.(Supplied: John Newman)
", "Ms Pryor says Ms Roberts retired from the stage in 1980.", "\"So that means that she was performing in her 60s and early 70s, which is quite an extraordinary career,\" Ms Pryor says.", "
'Rhythm, artistry, grace, poise'\u00a0
", "Looking back at her career in an ABC interview in 1988, Moi-Yo Miller estimated she had been sawn in half 11,800 times.", "", "
Moi-Yo Miller toured with Dante for years and was integral to his show's success.(Supplied: Australian Performing Arts Collection)
", "Born Mona Loretta Miller in 1914, her big break came when she was signed as an\u00a0assistant for Danish-born American magician Dante.", "\"Dante was very, very famous in his day, and she became his leading assistant \u2026 She was very proud to call herself an assistant but she brought so much to his show,\" Ms Pryor says.", "\"We might see women as being female assistants but so often it was a partnership. They might not have got top billing on these shows but they were very integral to the show's success.\"", "In addition to being the leading assistant, Ms Miller worked on the costumes, sets and lighting, as well as training the other female assistants.", "\"[Because of Moi-Yo], the show moved away from vaudeville and circus type performance, and it became very glamorous,\" Ms Pryor says.", "Ms Miller scrapped the circus-style music in favour of classical waltzes and replaced the showgirl outfits with stylish evening gowns.", "Publicity posters called Ms Miller \"Australia's most beautiful woman,\" while Dante once described her as the \"leading illusionista in the world \u2014 the combination of everything: of rhythm, artistry, grace and poise.\"", "", "
Working with Dante meant that Moi-Yo Miller toured the world.(Supplied: Charisse Kininmonth)
", "Working with Dante meant Ms Miller was able to travel the world, touring throughout Asia, Russia, Europe and the US.", "The team was in Hitler's Berlin when World War II\u00a0broke out and they had just six hours notice to pack up and get out.", "Accounts differ as to the origins of Ms Miller's\u00a0stage name, with some media reports saying it came from a tour of Japan, while others gave it Chinese origins.", "After Dante died in 1955, Ms Miller stepped away from the industry and focused on her family, but later in life, she spoke at magic conventions and events.", "She died in 2018, aged 104.", "
Slowly changing
", "Ms Pryor says stage magic continued to be a boys' club long after the careers of Ms Levante, Ms Roberts and Ms Miller.", "\"For example, the Magic Circle in the UK [an organisation that promotes magic] didn't admit women into its ranks until 1991,\" she says.", "While magic still has the reputation for being male-dominated, things are slowly changing in Australia.", "\"[There are] very accomplished magicians who are women these days, who make a wonderful career out of it,\" Ms\u00a0Pryor says.", "And this is in no small part thanks to the pioneering efforts of\u00a0Ms Levante, Ms Roberts and Ms Miller.", "Listen to a discussion with Cathy Pryor, the curator of the Rare Flowers and Golden Butterflies exhibition on ABC RN's Life Matters here.", "Listen to an in-depth exploration of Esme Levante's magical life on ABC RN's the History Listen here."]
